tsql-schema-only.title: SQL Server Tables with DURABILITY: SCHEMA_ONLY
tsql-schema-only.shortDescription: Use ultra-fast in-memory temporary tables without logging for ephemeral data.

content.mainTitle: SQL Server Tables with DURABILITY: SCHEMA_ONLY
content.overview: SQL Server allows creating memory-optimized tables with the DURABILITY = SCHEMA_ONLY option. These tables retain only their structure after a restart or failover, while data is lost. This feature eliminates transaction logging and provides exceptional performance for temporary or intermediate data that doesn't need to be persisted.

case1.title: Intermediate calculation tables
case1.description: Ideal for storing temporary calculation results that don't need to persist beyond the session. The absence of logging dramatically speeds up inserts and updates.

case2.title: Staging tables for ETL
case2.description: Perfect for extract, transform, and load (ETL) processes. Data is loaded into memory at high speed, transformed, then transferred to persistent tables. Staging doesn't require durability.

case3.title: User session management
case3.description: Excellent for tracking user session state in real-time. Sessions are inherently ephemeral: if the server restarts, users simply reconnect. Ultra-fast performance improves user experience.

summary.title: Summary
summary.text: Use DURABILITY = SCHEMA_ONLY when you need maximum performance for temporary data that doesn't need to survive a server restart. This option is particularly effective for staging tables, application caches, intermediate calculations, and session management.
pros: Exceptional performance: no transaction logging, all in-memory
Drastically reduces disk usage and I/O
Perfect for ephemeral or temporary data (staging, cache, sessions)
Table structure persists, facilitating automatic data recreation
cons: Complete data loss on restart or failover
Requires SQL Server 2014+ with In-Memory OLTP option enabled

goodPractices.title: Best practices
items: Reserve this option only for data that can be easily recreated or is temporary
Clearly document that data is not durable to avoid confusion
Properly size available memory to avoid resource issues
Use HASH indexes with an appropriate BUCKET_COUNT to optimize performance
Combine with DURABILITY = SCHEMA_AND_DATA for tables requiring persistence
